title: The Mean Inner Potential of Hematite- α-Fe2O3 across the Morin Transition
content: The mean inner potential (MIP) is defined as the volume averaged electrostatic (Coulomb) potential within a crystal with respect to vacuum [1]. It is a fundamental material property depending on composition, crystal structure and surfaces. We measured the MIP of crystals using off-axis electron holography (OAEH, see Fig. 1(a)) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), e.g. Refs. [2, 3]. The MIP is sensitive to the distribution of valence electrons, so we suggest its use as a chemical bonding parameter for solids: Hematite, α-Fe2O3, is a test case to the sensitivity of the MIP as a proposed bonding parameter because of the Morin antiferromagnetic phase transition.
